required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Non-opioid Based Pain Control After Thyroidectomy
clinical_study.official_title: Use of Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) in Minimizing Opioid Use for Patients Undergoing Thyroidectomy

brief_summary.textblock: Pain control modalities were evaluated after thyroidectomy.

detailed_description.textblock: Pain control modalities were evaluated after thyroidectomy. Patients were randomized to one of two pain control regimens. The control group received conventional opioid based post operative analgesia while the test group received an enhanced recovery after surgery (ERAS) based anesthesia with use of acetaminophen and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs for the post operative period with opioid medications available for break through pain only. Pain scores (measured on visual analog scale) and opioid use (measured in morphine equivalent dose) were measured after completion of the operation.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Randomized to one of two study groups

primary_outcome.description: Pain level from 0 (no pain) to 10 (worst pain imaginable).
Pain level from 0 (no pain) to 10 (worst pain imaginable).
Pain level from 0 (no pain) to 10 (worst pain imaginable).
Pain level from 0 (no pain) to 10 (worst pain imaginable).

secondary_outcome.time_frame: with the first 24 hours post operatively
secondary_outcome.description: the dose of opioid received by the patient

arm_group.arm_group_label: Acetaminophen and hydrocodone based pain control
arm_group.description: Patients receive acetaminophen 650mg every 4 for pain level 1-3, hydrocodone/acetaminophen 5/325mg every 4 for pain level 4-6, or hydrocodone/acetaminophen 10/650mg every 4 for pain level 7-10 on as needed basis.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Acetaminophen and ibuprofen based pain control
arm_group.description: Patients receive standing dose of acetaminophen 650mg every 8 hours and ibuprofen 800mg every 8 hours with alternating ibuprofen and acetaminophen every 4 hours.

intervention.intervention_name: Acetaminophen and hydrocodone based pain control
intervention.description: Patients receive acetaminophen 650mg every 4 for pain level 1-3, hydrocodone/acetaminophen 5/325mg every 4 for pain level 4-6, or hydrocodone/acetaminophen 10/650mg every 4 for pain level 7-10 on as needed basis.
intervention.arm_group_label: Acetaminophen and hydrocodone based pain control

intervention.intervention_name: Acetaminophen and ibuprofen based pain control
intervention.description: Patients receive standing dose of acetaminophen 650mg every 8 hours and ibuprofen 800mg every 8 hours with alternating ibuprofen and acetaminophen every 4 hours.
intervention.arm_group_label: Acetaminophen and ibuprofen based pain control

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- thyroid disease
Exclusion Criteria:
- currently on opioid pain medications
- on opioid pain meds in last 30 days
- cannot take non-opioid medications
- require more extensive operation than thyroidectomy

results_reference.citation: Francis DO, Randolph G, Davies L. Nationwide Variation in Rates of Thyroidectomy Among US Medicare Beneficiaries. JAMA Otolaryngol Head Neck Surg. 2017 Nov 1;143(11):1122-1125. doi: 10.1001/jamaoto.2017.1746.

Brummett CM, Waljee JF, Goesling J, Moser S, Lin P, Englesbe MJ, Bohnert ASB, Kheterpal S, Nallamothu BK. New Persistent Opioid Use After Minor and Major Surgical Procedures in US Adults. JAMA Surg. 2017 Jun 21;152(6):e170504. doi: 10.1001/jamasurg.2017.0504. Epub 2017 Jun 21. Erratum in: JAMA Surg. 2019 Mar 1;154(3):272.
Wilmore DW, Kehlet H. Management of patients in fast track surgery. BMJ. 2001 Feb 24;322(7284):473-6. Review.
Kehlet H, Wilmore DW. Multimodal strategies to improve surgical outcome. Am J Surg. 2002 Jun;183(6):630-41. Review.
